This material or any portion hereof may not be reprinted, sold or redistributed without the written consent of J.P. Morgan.
APAC Energy Transition (Alan Hon / Hannah L Lee)

Tightness and Tribulations: Ten Fresh Takes on Clean Energy Supply The road to a clean energy future is long (and uncertain). While the energy transition remains an overarching theme, history has shown that renewable energy build- out at scale does not necessarily translate into returns at all points of the value chain. Industry cycles, technological advancement, and geopolitics all come into play. In this report, we give10 answers to questions relating to the transition on three main topics: 1) Which transition value chains are in supply tightness or emerging as important ones? 2) Where are geopolitical risks less well understood? 3) Which transition technologies will be the next game changers? JPM- covered stocks that emerge as our top picks include: Bannerman Energy (BMN), CATL- A, Hyundai Electric, Hyosung Heavy, ILU, LG Chem, LG Energy Solution, Orient Cables, Sieyuan and Tenaga.
Luxshare - A (002475. SZ, OW - Rmb46.10), China (Billy Feng) Rising contribution from strong auto/communication; better-than- expected

consolidation; reiterate Ow During the earnings call, management addressed: 1) strong revenue growth in auto and communication segments in 1H25, attributable to positive portfolio expansion, which is expected to boost growth continuously; 2) sustainable and resilient growth outlook, even in a complex macro situation, backed by its diversified business, globalized capacity, high- quality delivery and its superior capability of intelligent manufacture; and, 3) better- than- expected consolidation of newly acquired business (including Leoni and ODM business, both settled in July). We expect a better revenue mix (rising contribution from high- margin auto and communication segments) and project a \(26\%\) earnings CAGR in 2024- 27. We reiterate Ow on Luxshare with an extended Jun- 26 PT of Rmb63.
Huaqin Technology - A (603296. SS, OW - Rmb96.06), China (Cherry Liu / Billy Feng)

Strong growth across segments in 1H25; optimistic on AI momentum and growth outlook; reiterate Ow Key takeaways from Huaqin's earnings call include: 1) strong earnings growth of \(46\%\) yoy in 1H25 was driven by accelerating AI server delivery and strong momentum in smartphone/PC/wearable areas; 2) GPM dropped sequentially in 2Q25, due to product mix change, but is expected to recover with a better mix; 3) management expects \(>Rmb40bn\) datacenter revenue in 2025 and further growth ahead, given continuous demand from CSPs and Huaqin's full- stack portfolio with share- gain potential; and 4) an unchanged target of a \(\sim 17\%\) revenue CAGR and stronger earnings growth with margin expansion in 2024- 30. We consider Huaqin's growth outlook to be intact, supported by strong momentum across its diversified layout; reiterate Ow with a Jun- 26 PT of Rmb115.
Innovent Biologics (1801) (1801. HK, OW - HK\\$90.65), China (Yang Huang)

Raise PT post strong 1H25; reiterate as top pick in China biopharma While product sales were already pre- announced, Innovent's 1H25 GPM and opex both came in better than our expectations. We are impressed by the strong momentum in the company's commercialized products and the progress of its pipeline assets. As part of its globalization initiative, Innovent is actively launching global trials for its oncology and other assets while exploring strategic BD (business development) opportunities. Its early pipeline assets are progressing smoothly, demonstrating solid potential to drive the next phase of growth. Overall, we view Innovent as one of the most diversified and innovative biopharma companies in China. We reiterate it as our top pick in China biopharma, raise our price target, and maintain an OW rating.

Li Auto's (Li) 2Q25 results came in about \(17\%\) below JPME (GAAP earnings), dragged by higher- than- expected opex while vehicle GPM was in line. Mgmt highlighted the company's LT strategies, including product pipeline, autonomous driving roadmap, overseas ambitions and financial outlook. Overall, we welcome the company's initiatives, though our reservations lie in rising competition, in particular in the mid- to high- end BEV SUVs that are Li's focus (i8 and coming i6 in Sept). The company's 3Q25 volume guidance (16- 21% below our previous estimate) suggests potential downside to consensus volume/earnings projections in the rest of the year and 2026. The stock is down \(2\%\) YTD (MSCI China Autos \(+30\%\) ). We lower our 2025/26 estimates by \(42\% /14\%\) and stay Neutral.

We think 1H25 marks the trough of profitability. Zhongsheng (ZS)'s 1H25 earnings were \(\sim 20\%\) shy of JPME, dragged by record low margins in new car sales as a result of 1) fierce price competition in auto market and 2) limited rebate from OEMs, which we expect to increase meaningfully in 2H25. We notice industry- wide price discounts hit record highs by June - right before the Chinese government intervened and launched its anti- involution campaign to curb irrational pricing behavior among OEMs. We upgraded ZS to OW on July 28 (here) on long- term expectations that ZS will see structural profitability improvement from anti- involution efforts in the next 1- 2 years. This view remains intact.

India will be organising its fourth SEMICON event next week from 2- 4 September in New Delhi. The event is organised by India Semiconductor Mission (ISM) which has outlayed Rs760bn to develop a semiconductor ecosystem in India across semiconductor fabs, display fabs, OSAT and design. The Indian government has already approved 10 semiconductor plants so far with cumulative investments of Rs1600bn of which one plant is of Kaynes where it will be investing Rs33bn. We will watch out for: 1) any potential announcement by the government around expanding the Rs760bn initial outlay given increased interest from companies in setting up semiconductor plants, and 2) any potential announcement by Kaynes on either offtake agreements or technology partnership on OSAT.

Our aggregate measure of investor positioning in Asia now sits around the 85th %ile (having gone as high as \(97^{\text{th}}\) %ile in July). While this would normally be considered a significant headwind, the global policy easing and China liquidity surge currently underway is providing a strong counter force. In this context, we believe the equity bull market will remain intact and any correction/consolidation will present a buying opportunity. However, it is important to manage risks where positioning is particularly crowded. Looking across LO, HF and Quant investors, we note the highest crowding in Taiwan Tech/Semis and Indo Financials, followed by China Growth stocks (semis, consumer and biotech). Alongside this, ongoing support from monetary policy should eventually warrant a widening of the leadership and outperformance of Cyclicals. We are upgrading the Materials sector to Ow in the AxJ region following our recent allocation changes in India (see report). Within the AxJ region, our pecking order is Korea \(>\) India \(>\) China \(>\) Taiwan \(>\) ASEAN. Our key OwS are: China Tech, Internet, Healthcare, Materials, select Financial/Industrials; India Financials, Consumer ex Auto, Materials, Real Estate, Hospitals, select power/defense; Korea Financials, Tech, Holdco; TSMC in Taiwan; and ASEAN Financials, Real Estate, Utilities, Healthcare, IT.

Tightness and Tribulations: Ten Fresh Takes on Clean Energy Supply

The road to a clean energy future is long (and uncertain). While the energy transition remains an overarching theme, history has shown that renewable energy build- out at scale does not necessarily translate into returns at all points of the value chain. Industry cycles, technological advancement, and geopolitics all come into play. In this report, we give10 answers to questions relating to the transition on three main topics: 1) Which transition value chains are in supply tightness or emerging as important ones? 2) Where are geopolitical risks less well understood? 3) Which transition technologies will be the next game changers? JPM- covered stocks that emerge as our top picks include: Bannerman Energy (BMN), CATL- A, Hyundai Electric, Hyosung Heavy, ILU, LG Chem, LG Energy Solution, Orient Cables, Sieyuan and Tenaga.

APAC leads the world in energy transition investment, making up \(\sim 50\%\) of the world's US\\$2.1tn in 2024. APAC also had the highest growth of \(21\%\) (vs. AMER/EMEA's \(+7\% / - 2\%\) for the same year; and in clean technology net exports, with an amount of US\\$191bn. In recent years, the quest for energy to fuel AI DC has exacerbated the need for clean electricity. Despite a strong thesis, finding investment opportunities is complex due to industry cycles and geopolitics.

Five supply chains in focus. (1) APAC submarine cable makers riding on EU offshore wind and ASEAN/ME grid interconnection demand; (2) Australia uranium miners and US HALEU (high assay low- enriched uranium) enrichment capacity set to benefit from the global nuclear revival; (3) APAC Nuclear Equipment makers, which are relevant to US SMR development; (4) US- made ESS battery supplies (led by Korean companies) benefitting from OBBB restriction on China supply; leading supplier CATL benefitting from ex- US demand growth; (5) Asia power equipment companies benefitting from transformer and HVDC equipment supply tightness. In Figure 6, we list relevant names. Key OW- rated names within APAC are BMN, CATL- A, Hyundai Electric, Hyosung, ILU, LG Chem, LG Energy Solution, Orient Cables, Sieyuan and Tenaga.

Three geopolitical risks to watch for. We identify three areas where we think geopolitical risks are not well understood: 1) Russia supplied \(>25\%\) of US uranium enrichment demand in 2023; 2) China relies on the US for high- purity quartz \((70\% - 90\%\) of supply) for solar manufacturing; and 3) China's rare- earth exports. In Figure 7, we list examples of companies in these areas.

Two emerging technologies that could be game changers. Solar and offshore wind are the cheapest sources of new- build electricity, covering \(>70\%\) of global GDP. For reference, LCOE for solar has improved by \(\sim 80\%\) over the last decade on technological improvements. Clean tech could be a disruptor of the world's energy landscape. Looking ahead, among a few others, we highlight nuclear fusion and hydropower as potential game changers.
Utilities and Environmental

Rising contribution from strong auto/communication; better- than- expected consolidation; reiterate OW

During the earnings call, management addressed: 1) strong revenue growth in auto and communication segments in 1H25, attributable to positive portfolio expansion, which is expected to boost growth continuously; 2) sustainable and resilient growth outlook, even in a complex macro situation, backed by its diversified business, globalized capacity, high- quality delivery and its superior capability of intelligent manufacture; and, 3) better- than- expected consolidation of newly acquired business (including Leoni and ODM business, both settled in July). We expect a better revenue mix (rising contribution from high- margin auto and communication segments) and project a \(26\%\) earnings CAGR in 2024- 27. We reiterate OW on Luxshare with an extended Jun- 26 PT of Rmb63.

- Optimistic growth outlook for auto/communication. Dongguan Luxshare Technology (one of Luxshare's subsidiaries), focusing on the communication business, achieved revenue of Rmb6.5bn and net profit of Rmb825mn in 1H25, indicating a NPM of \(13\%\) , vs the average NPM of \(6\%\) for Luxshare. After strong growth in 1H25, Luxshare expects continuous momentum with more new projects moving into mass production. In the auto space, Luxshare achieved pleasant progress in terms of design wins in smart driving space, which is expected to boost further growth; meanwhile, the company managed better-than-expected consolidation on Leoni (acquisition settled in early July), and aims to turn profitable in 2025 and enhance profitability going forward.

- Better-than-expected ODM consolidation also. Luxshare started its ODM consolidation since beginning this year and has achieved settlement in early July. As of now, as stated in the earnings call, the company saw better-than-expected consolidation, in terms of R&D and manufacture synergies, as well as operating efficiency improvements. On top of its current capacity layout, Luxshare plans to increase capacity in India, which is set to fulfill ODM clients' need and enhance stickiness, though this features lower margins.

- Lift PT and reiterate OW. We fine tune our 2025-27 earnings forecasts to reflect mixed impacts from 1) acquisitions of Leoni and ODM business from Wingtech (incremental revenue but potential net loss in near term, though limited), 2) stronger growth outlook for auto and communication business, and 3) upbeat iPhone volume for 2H25. We now project \(26\%\) earnings CAGR for Luxshare in 2024-27 and extend our PT to Jun-26 at Rmb63, based on 19x 1yr forward PE (prev: 18x). We expect a re-rate from current valuation of 15x 2026E PE and reiterate OW.
Price Target (Jun- 26): Rmb63.00 Prior (Dec- 25): Rmb53.00

Strong growth across segments in 1H25; optimistic on Al momentum and growth outlook; reiterate OW

Key takeaways from Huaqin's earnings call include: 1) strong earnings growth of \(46\%\) yoy in 1H25 was driven by accelerating Al server delivery and strong momentum in smartphone/PC/wearable areas; 2) GPM dropped sequentially in 2Q25, due to product mix change, but is expected to recover with a better mix; 3) management expects \(>Rmb40bn\) datacenter revenue in 2025 and further growth ahead, given continuous demand from CSPs and Huaqin's full- stack portfolio with share- gain potential; and 4) an unchanged target of a \(\sim 17\%\) revenue CAGR and stronger earnings growth with margin expansion in 2024- 30. We consider Huaqin's growth outlook to be intact, supported by strong momentum across its diversified layout; reiterate OW with a Jun- 26 PT of Rmb115.

Highlights of the 1H25 results. Huaqin achieved \(116\% /128\%\) yoy revenue growth in its intelligent terminal/high performance computing segments in 1H25, which was driven not only by accelerating Al server delivery, but also helped by growing market share in smartphone, PC and wearables (with portfolio expansion). The GPM dropped sequentially by 1.3ppt to \(7.1\%\) due to revenue mix change (rising contribution from low- margin AI server), but is expected to recover, backed by an improving mix, especially with an increasing contribution from high- margin wearables and switches.

Optimistic outlook for 2H25; unchanged compound growth target. While GPU supply uncertainty remains, Huaqin expects \(>Rmb40bn\) datacenter revenue and \(>Rmb160bn\) total revenue for 2025, with strong growth in the smartphone, PC, and wearables segments continuing in 2H25. Management addressed its optimistic outlook for robust demand in the AI space, believing its full- stack product portfolio (covering AI server, general server and switch) will support its share gains and persistent revenue growth (with improving margin from a better mix). Huaqin also stated an unchanged target of a \(\sim 17\%\) revenue CAGR and stronger earnings growth for 2024- 30, with \(\sim 25\%\) revenue generated from each of the smartphone, PC+ and datacenter segments, and the rest from auto (pleasant progress in 2025), wearables, robots, etc.

Reiterate OW. Huaqin has underperformed its major peer Inspur by 11ppt since July, which we attribute to its limited revenue exposure to domestic GPU platforms and headwinds from its ESOP share disposal plan. We believe investors have been overly concerned on such impact and we expect Huaqin to ramp up its revenue on domestic GPU platform. Also, we think investors may be underestimating Huaqin's potential upside in the PC space and earnings contributions from high- margin wearables/switches. We fine tune our earnings forecasts and reiterate our OW rating with a revised Jun- 26 PT of Rmb115, based on an unchanged 21x 1- year forward P/E.
Price Target (Jun- 26): Rmb115.00 Prior (Jun- 26): Rmb110.00

Raise PT post strong 1H25; reiterate as top pick in China biopharma

While product sales were already pre- announced, Innovent's 1H25 GPM and opex both came in better than our expectations. We are impressed by the strong momentum in the company's commercialized products and the progress of its pipeline assets. As part of its globalization initiative, Innovent is actively launching global trials for its oncology and other assets while exploring strategic BD (business development) opportunities. Its early pipeline assets are progressing smoothly, demonstrating solid potential to drive the next phase of growth. Overall, we view Innovent as one of the most diversified and innovative biopharma companies in China. We reiterate it as our top pick in China biopharma, raise our price target, and maintain an OW rating.

- Management reiterates guidance to achieve EBITDA breakeven this year without considering BD income and Rmb20bn of sales in FY27E. 1H25 sales grew 51% YoY, driven by a 37% increase in product sales and the recognition of an upfront payment from Roche. Product GPM has consistently expanded, reaching 84% in 1H25, due to efficiency improvements and economies of scale. Opex remains disciplined. Although R&D investment will increase in 2H25 with the commencement of more late-stage/global trials, management expects it to remain within US\\$300-400mn. The S&M expense ratio could also rise in 2H25 as Innovent enhances its multi-channel strategy for its GLP-1 franchise and ramps up investments ahead of the pickankibart (IL-23p19) launch.

- IBI363 (PD-1/IL-2α-bias bispecific antibody) and IBI343 (CLDN18.2 ADC) remain the company's near-term focus. IBI363 will start its first global Ph3 trial in I/O (immuno-oncology) - resistant sqNSCLC (squamous non-small cell lung cancer) in 2H25. The company plans to launch a global Ph3 trial for IBI343 in 2L+ PDAC (pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma). While IBI363 has shown promising efficacy in various indications, Innovent's high level strategy for IBI363 is to start with cold tumors and I/O resistant indications and advance from late line to front line. The company has already initiated Ph1b/2 trials in 1L NSCLC and 1L MSS CRC (microsatellite stability colorectal cancer) with potential preliminary data readout in 2026.
- Innovent also has a portfolio of innovative drugs, including IBI3001 (EGFR/B7H3 ADC) and IBI3020 (CEACAM5 dual-

2Q25 shy of expectations; rising headwinds likely ahead

Li Auto's (Li) 2Q25 results came in about \(17\%\) below JPMc (GAAP earnings), dragged by higher- than- expected opex while vehicle GPM was in line. Mgmt highlighted the company's LT strategies, including product pipeline, autonomous driving roadmap, overseas ambitions and financial outlook. Overall, we welcome the company's initiatives, though our reservations lie in rising competition, in particular in the mid- to high- end BEV SUVs that are Li's focus (i8 and coming i6 in Sept). The company's 3Q25 volume guidance \((16 - 21\%)\) below our previous estimate) suggests potential downside to consensus volume/earnings projections in the rest of the year and 2026. The stock is down \(2\%\) YTD (MSCI China Autos \(+30\%\) ). We lower our 2025/26 estimates by \(42\% /14\%\) and stay Neutral.

- Mgmt initiatives and JPMc: 1) New model roadmap: On the result call, mgmt reiterated the company's third BEV, the i6 SUV, is on track to launch in late Sept, followed by immediate delivery from 4Q25. We expect the i6 to be priced reasonably, starting around Rmb230k, hence driving monthly sales of close to 10k after fully ramped. We will watch three competing models in either similar addressable markets or price segments in the next 1-2 quarters: NIO's Onvo L80 (JPMc priced around Rmb230k, or Rmb160k with battery leasing option), NIO's ES6 (\~Rmb300k, or toward Rmb230k with battery leasing), Leapmotor's D-series 5/6 seater large SUV (BEV and EREV versions) at the Paris auto show in Oct (\~Rmb200-300k). 2) AI and Autonomous driving roadmap: Mgmt highlighted it plans to invest over Rmb6bn in AI this year and they have taped out its first in-house AI chip. On ADAS, the VLA driver large model is set to be deployed on all AD Max models via OTA updates by mid-Sept. 3). Potential overseas strategy: Li Auto plans to expand globally, focusing on markets in the Middle East, Central Asia, and Europe. 4) Comprehensive charging network to enhance user experience: The company currently operates 3,100 charging stations and plans to reach 4,000 by the end of the year.

- 2Q25 earnings highlights and our revisions: 1) Revenue grew by \(17\%\) qoq on volume growth of \(20\%\) in 2Q25. We now project Li's FY25 volume to reach 430k units, or a \(14\%\) yoy decline. 2) 2Q25 GPM contracted slightly to \(20.1\%\) in 2Q25 from \(20.5\%\) in 1Q25, within which vehicle GPM dropped from \(19.8\%\) in 1Q25 to \(19.4\%\) due mainly to intensified competition from 2Q. 3) Opex ratio fell to \(18.3\%\) in 2Q25 from \(19.5\%\) in 1Q25. Overall, the company reported net profit of Rmb1.1bn (or non-GAAP Rmb1.5bn).
- Stay Neutral. Our Jun-26 PTs are US\\(26/HKS100 based on a blended average of 0.6x 2026E EV/sales, 1.0x 2026E P/S and 14x 2026E P/E after our earnings revisions.
Bottoming out, maintain OW

We think 1H25 marks the trough of profitability. Zhongsheng (ZS)'s 1H25 earnings were \(\sim 20\%\) shy of JPMc, dragged by record low margins in new car sales as a result of 1) fierce price competition in auto market and 2) limited rebate from OEMs, which we expect to increase meaningfully in 2H25. We notice industry- wide price discounts hit record highs by June - right before the Chinese government intervened and launched its anti- involution campaign to curb irrational pricing behavior among OEMs. We upgraded ZS to OW on July 28 (here) on long- term expectations that ZS will see structural profitability improvement from anti- involution efforts in the next 1- 2 years. This view remains intact.

Recap of our LT thesis and mgmt comments on the result call: 1) Initiatives from Benz and BMW: At JPMorgan's recent global auto forum in London (here), we learnt and were encouraged by Benz and BMW's targets to restructure their dealer networks by closing \(\sim 15 - 20\%\) of poor quality stores in China in the next year. This should benefit leading players including ZS. Our channel checks suggest Benz and BMW have closed \(\sim 4\%\) of their stores in China in recent months. 2) Benz, which accounted for \(35\%\) of ZS' new car sales revenue in 1H25, is entering into a powerful product cycle in 2026- 27 with 31 new or facelifted models across the BEV and ICE portfolio. We hence expect narrowing price discounts for Benz (currently c. \(15 - 20\%\) ) and potentially other premium brands in the next two years; 3) Overseas expansion for selected mainland Chinese brands likely starting in Hong Kong, Macau or neighboring markets given much higher GPM (generally \(8 - 10\%\) ) in overseas markets vs. domestic \((- 2 - 4\%)\) ; we would welcome this move if it materializes. 4) Anticipated further rebate from OEMs in 2H25: OEMs' rebate or compensation collectively translated into \(>Rmb15k\) per car in 2024 but was fairly limited in 1H25, hence we believe OEMs will offer rebates to quality dealers such as ZS in 2H25 rather than to smaller dealers that may be subject to closure.

1H25 result highlights: 1) New car sales fell by \(5\%\) yoy due to \(2\%\) yoy volume decline and \(5\%\) ASP contraction. GPM contracted to \(- 4.1\%\) due to fierce price competition and narrowing OEM rebate in 1H25. We expect OEM rebates to increase meaningfully in 2H25, driving an improved GPM in 2H. 2) Aftermarket business: revenue was sustained with GPM remaining solid at \(47.4\%\) . 3) Opex ratio widened slightly by 0.1ppt to \(5.9\%\) in 1H25. Overall, net profit slipped by \(36\%\) yoy, in part due to higher base last year.

Earnings revisions and investor feedback on our recent upgrade: We trim ZS' 2025/26 estimates by \(\sim 16\% /12\%\) to reflect the 1H25 run rate. Our LT positive stance remains unchanged. Investor feedback towards our recent upgrade has been generally positive; the main "pushback" is most investors think noticeable profitability improvement will not be seen until 4Q25/ 1Q26 or beyond - this is also our base case.
Sources for: Style Exposure - J.P. Morgan Global Markets Strategy; all other tables are company data and J.P. Morgan estimates.

Pre- cursor to the India SEMICON event next week

India will be organising its fourth SEMICON event next week from 2- 4 September in New Delhi. The event is organised by India Semiconductor Mission (ISM) which has outlayed Rs760bn to develop a semiconductor ecosystem in India across semiconductor fabs, display fabs, OSAT and design. The Indian government has already approved 10 semiconductor plants so far with cumulative investments of Rs1600bn of which one plant is of Kaynes where it will be investing Rs33bn. We will watch out for: 1) any potential announcement by the government around expanding the Rs760bn initial outlay given increased interest from companies in setting up semiconductor plants, and 2) any potential announcement by Kaynes on either offtake agreements or technology partnership on OSAT.

- India SEMICON event next week. India will be organising its fourth SEMICON event next week from 2-4 Sept in New Delhi. The event is organised by ISM that has outlayed Rs760bn to develop semiconductor ecosystem in India across semiconductor fabs, display fabs, OSAT and design.

- 10 semiconductor plants have received approvals so far. The Indian government has so far approved 10 semiconductor plants with cumulative investments of Rs1600bn. As part of the Rs760bn outlay, the central government will provide subsidies in the form of 50% of the capex done by companies on a pari-passu basis. On top of this, there will be state level subsidies as well of around 20-25% of the capex, however, this comes post the commencement of operation. The India OSAT market is at a very nascent stage with a size of \(35mn in FY25, compared to the global OSAT market of\) 48bn.

- Kaynes has OSAT exposure. Amongst our coverage, Kaynes is the only one that has participated in the semiconductor scheme with capex of Rs33bn to setup OSAT facility in Sanand, Gujarat. The facility will have output of 6.33mn chips per day and is on track to start commercial production in Dec'25 with revenues coming from 4QFY26. It has signed three clients on OSAT - a US-based client, an Indian client who has acquired a Japanese business, and a German client.

- What to watch out for? At the SEMICON event, we will watch out for: 1) any potential announcement by the government around expanding the Rs760bn initial outlay given increased interest from companies in setting up semiconductor plants, and 2) any potential announcement by Kaynes on either offtake agreements or technology partnership on OSAT.
IT Services, EMS, Telecom, and Internet Research

This material is neither intended to be distributed to Mainland China investors nor to provide securities investment consultancy services within the territory of Mainland China. Liquidity floats all, but manage risks in crowded spaces

Our aggregate measure of investor positioning in Asia now sits around the 85th %ile (having gone as high as \(97^{\text{th}}\) %ile in July - Figure 1). While this would normally be considered a significant headwind, the global policy easing and China liquidity surge currently underway is providing a strong counter force. In this context, we believe the equity bull market will remain intact and any correction/ consolidation will present a buying opportunity. However, it is important to manage risks where positioning is particularly crowded. Looking across LO, HF and Quant investors, we note the highest crowding in Taiwan Tech/Semis and Indo Financials, followed by China Growth stocks (semis, consumer and biotech). Alongside this, ongoing support from monetary policy should eventually warrant a widening of the leadership and outperformance of Cyclicals. We are upgrading the Materials sector to Ow in the AxJ region following our recent allocation changes in India (see report). Within the AxJ region, our pecking order is Korea > India > China > Taiwan > ASEAN. Our key OwS are: China Tech, Internet, Healthcare, Materials, select Financial/Industrials; India Financials, Consumer ex Auto, Materials, Real Estate, Hospitals, select power/defense; Korea Financials, Tech, Holdco; TSMC in Taiwan; and ASEAN Financials, Real Estate, Utilities, Healthcare, IT.

- Crowded market segments in Asia: For LO investors, their key OwS are in China Internet, China Consumer, Taiwan Tech, Korea Tech, India Banks and Indo Banks (Figure 8). Among single stocks, relative to benchmark weight, most crowded positions are in BCA, TME, Netease, Hana, Kia, Mediatek and Delta. For HFs, net positioning is currently most elevated in Cap Goods, Tech (Hardware and Semis) and Financial Services (Figure 11). For AI and Semis overall, JPM Prime book data show record high net positioning in both Mag 7 stocks and in US Semiconductors sector (Figure 12-13). From a factor lens, Growth is starting to look crowded in China after the recent strong performance (Figure 16). Crowding in Momentum in Korea is starting to unwind, but still elevated. Quality/Growth looks extremely crowded in Taiwan. Across all of North Asia, Defensives and Value look extremely uncrowded. No factor looks particularly crowded or uncrowded in India.

- Positioning themes by market: (1) China: The recent surge in onshore liquidity may be temporary, but, longer-term, apart from national team purchases and household re-allocation from cash/MMF into equities, there are also sticky institutional flows from private pensions, new insurance premiums, and regulators' mandates on 10% annual increase in mutual funds' equity holdings. (2) Taiwan: With EM/Asia investors starting to hit mandate constraints on TSMC again, we note that global funds, global TMT funds, hedge funds and sovereign investors are likely all unconstrained in terms of room to buy. For the largest of these cohorts, global funds have so far only neutralized previous UWs in the stock. (3) Korea: While retail investors are yet to meaningfully re-allocate towards local equities, the decline in their
